#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Solo Drive
#Text=a 100 Foot Power Yacht
#Text=Have you wondered how to solo drive a power yacht ?
#Text=If you do n't know , then this guide will get you started in driving your new power ( engine driven ) yacht away from the dock , around the harbor , and returning it to the dock safely .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Understand the basics about yachts .
#Text=Before you actually attempt to drive the yacht , sit in the cabin a few days and practice operating the marine radio and other communications and safety equipment .
#Text=Learn the proper radio frequencies for emergencies :
#Text=The International Distress frequency is 156.80Mhz
#Text=Coast Guard and Harbor Patrol 157.10Mhz
#Text=Ship to ship ( calling frequency ) 156.45Mhz
#Text=Ship to shore 156.70Mhz
#Text=Marine Operator ( to make a phone call ) 157.20Mhz .
#Text=These are just a few channels . — Check your area for the preferred channels in use .
#Text=Your VHF radio has a range of more than and a cell phone wo n't help much at sea .
#Text=Apply to the FCC ( Federal Communications Commission ) for your operator 's license , so you can operate the radios legally .
#Text=If you have more interest in ship radio try this , the website for the Commercial Radio Operator License Program .
#Text=Read about who needs what kind of license , and find information on obtaining the licenses .
#Text=Anyone who operates a boat needs to receive their " Boating Safety I.D. Card and Certificate . "
#Text=This can be done by taking a class from the U.S. Coastguard 's list of safety courses and passing the final exam .
#Text=Learn the yacht steering controls .
#Text=Most will have a steering wheel and two throttles .
#Text=These controls are required for sufficient steering of the boat .
#Text=The steering wheel will not do a good job of steering at slow speeds in a tight harbor .
#Text=The engines do most of the steering at slow speeds .
#Text=The engines alone can steer your boat .
#Text=For example , to make a right turn around in a tight area , advance the left throttle slowly while retarding the right throttle the same amount .
#Text=This is called differential steering .
#Text=If you do this properly you will make the turn without ever moving the boat forward or backward .
#Text=Of course you will have to practice this for a long time to perfect it .
#Text=In a car , you can idle the engine and hold the brake to stop .
#Text=In a boat , you are always at the mercy of the wind and tide .
#Text=The only way to hold your position is with differential steering with the engines at all times .
#Text=Do n't say left or right in a boat .
#Text=The terms for the four directions are port , starboard , forward and aft .
#Text=Leave the dock .
#Text=Think about your limits and do n’t try to drive away in a yacht without the required crew members .
#Text=Depending on the size of the yacht , it may require no crew members or several crew members .
#Text=A yacht can be driven alone with the help of a dock hand to untie the yacht from the dock and also help when you return to the dock .
#Text=Learn about cruising .
#Text=When you think you can control the boat , try cruising in a straight line .
#Text=Use partial throttle , equally on both engines , to cruise forward in a straight line .
#Text=Use the steering wheel while cruising for directional control .
#Text=If something gets in your way just reduce the throttles to slow down .
#Text=If you need to stop quicker , reverse both engines equally just enough to stop forward motion .
#Text=This is where you may need to go to differential engines to hold position .
#Text=Return to the dock .
#Text=Docking is the most difficult to master , and the most dangerous .
#Text=A lot of damage will result if you do this wrong .
#Text=Try to practice docking in a calm wind first .
#Text=If you 're docking on the port side , try using the starboard engine forward and aft and repeat this maneuver .
#Text=The boat should ease to port side slowly .
#Text=This is where you really need a dock crew , especially in a little wind .
#Text=Some yachts have side thrusters to help move the boat sideways .
#Text=This will make docking a lot smoother .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Do n’t try driving the yacht in a strong wind or as a beginner .
#Text=Even a mild wind can cause loss of control and a bad crash into the yacht tied up to the dock next to you .
#Text=Practice moving the boat sideways using the differential steering method .
#Text=Practice until you have full control of the position you want , not where the boat wants to go .
#Text=Remember , a powerboat approaching on your right has the right-of-way .
#Text=A sailboat , using sails ( not power ) always has the right-of-way in all situations .
#Text=There are many more rules , so study boating rules before going out into a crowded harbor .
#Text=Practice the steering circles in an area with lots of room , near your docking area .
#Text=Most harbors have a speed limit of from 3 to 5 knots .
#Text=The way to tell if you 're speeding is to look at your wake ( a V shaped wave behind your boat ) .
#Text=If you have a wake you 're too fast .
#Text=That 's all the Harbor Patrol looks for to tell if you 're speeding .
#Text=So , do n't open it up until you 're out of the harbor .
